facts.text: The 33rd U.S. President, assuming office after FDR died.
Famous for the sign on his desk: 'The Buck Stops Here'.
Authorized the use of atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
Won the 1948 election despite newspapers printing 'Dewey Defeats Truman'.
America's 'Girl Next Door' and top box office star of the era.
Famous for the song 'Que Sera, Sera' (Whatever Will Be, Will Be).
She was a massive animal welfare activist in her later life.
Rumored to be terrified of flying, she rarely traveled.
Refers to the Communist Party takeover in 1949 under Mao Zedong.
The previous government fled to the island of Taiwan.
Renamed the country the 'People's Republic of China'.
The 'Little Red Book' of Mao's quotes became a mandatory accessory.
Known as the 'Prince of Wails' for his emotional crying while singing.
He was partially deaf and wore a hearing aid on stage.
His energetic style was a major precursor to Rock 'n' Roll.
Tony Bennett called him the 'father of rock and roll'.
A smash hit Broadway musical by Rodgers & Hammerstein.
Controversial for its time because it addressed racial prejudice.
Features the classic song 'Some Enchanted Evening'.
Won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 1950.
The inventor of the modern gossip column.
Famous for his staccato radio delivery: 'Good evening, Mr. and Mrs. America!'
He coined slang words like 'scram' and 'pushover'.
He carried a gun and often rode along with police.
Nicknamed 'Joltin' Joe' and 'The Yankee Clipper'.
Still holds the record for a 56-game hitting streak (1941).
Married Marilyn Monroe in 1954 (it lasted 9 months).
After Marilyn died, he sent roses to her grave 3 times a week for 20 years.
U.S. Senator who led the 'Red Scare' witch hunts.
Claimed he had a list of 205 communists in the State Department.
His aggressive interrogation tactics became known as 'McCarthyism'.
He was eventually censured by the Senate and died of alcoholism.
First mentioned here for being elected to the Senate in 1950.
Gave the famous 'Checkers' speech to deny corruption (Checkers was his dog).
The only U.S. President to resign from office (Watergate).
He was a skilled pianist and played on TV.
An iconic American car manufacturer known for 'bullet-nose' designs.
They originally started making wagons in the 1850s.
The company went bust in the 60s, unable to compete with the Big Three.
The Muppet movie features a 1951 Studebaker.
TV exploded in the 50s; ownership went from 9% to 90%.
Color broadcasting began in 1953 but took years to catch on.
Changed politics forever (JFK vs Nixon debate).
The first TV remote was called the 'Lazy Bone'.
Reference to the Korean War (1950-1953).
Often called 'The Forgotten War'.
The country was split at the 38th Parallel.
The war never officially ended; they just signed a truce.
Born Norma Jeane Mortenson.
The ultimate sex symbol of the 1950s.
Famously sang 'Happy Birthday, Mr. President' to JFK.
Her dress blowing up in 'The Seven Year Itch' is iconic.
Julius and Ethel Rosenberg were convicted of spying for the Soviets.
They were executed by electric chair in 1953.
They were accused of passing atomic bomb secrets.
It was the first execution of civilians for espionage in US history.
The Hydrogen Bomb (thermonuclear weapon).
First tested in 1952 ('Ivy Mike') on Enewetak Atoll.
It was 1,000 times more powerful than the Hiroshima bomb.
The test island was completely vaporized.
Refers to Sugar Ray Robinson, widely considered the best boxer ever.
He drove a famous pink Cadillac.
Held the Welterweight and Middleweight titles.
He created the concept of the athlete 'entourage'.
The 'truce village' on the border of North and South Korea.
Where the Korean Armistice Agreement was signed.
The 'Blue Buildings' straddle the border line exactly.
Soldiers from both sides stare at each other all day here.
Marlon Brando changed acting forever with 'The Method'.
Famous for yelling 'STELLA!' in A Streetcar Named Desire.
He refused his Godfather Oscar to protest treatment of Native Americans.
He bought his own private island chain in Tahiti.
Rodgers and Hammerstein musical about the King of Siam.
Yul Brynner played the King 4,625 times over 34 years.
He shaved his head for the role and kept it that way forever.
The movie is banned in Thailand for disrespecting the monarchy.
Novel by J.D. Salinger published in 1951.
The protagonist, Holden Caulfield, hates 'phonies'.
Mark David Chapman was reading it when he shot John Lennon.
It is one of the most censored books in US school history.
